channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Kerry and Zarif Turn to Selling Nuclear Deal to Skeptics Back Home
item.description: Having finally reached an interim agreement to freeze Iran’s nuclear program, Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Javad Zarif, turned their attention to selling the deal to skeptics back home.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Pakistani Party Identifies Man It Says Is C.I.A. Station Chief
item.description: The political party of former cricket star Imran Khan apparently revealed the name in an escalation of its campaign to end American drone strikes in the country.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Orphans, Friends and Neighbors Struggle to Endure in Typhoon’s Wake
item.description: Acts of heroism abound in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan, often with a special emphasis on ensuring the survival of children.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jomar Pascua cooked food for his siblings at an elementary school in Tacloban.

item.title: Protesters Take Drive to Oust Government Beyond Bangkok
item.description: Antigovernment demonstrators massed at over a dozen municipal buildings across Thailand on Wednesday and occupied a ministry building for a third day.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment demonstrators rallied in Bangkok on Wednesday.

item.title: Louis Vuitton Comes to Red Square, and Moscow Is Not Pleased
item.description: The designer has built a temporary, two-story replica of a traveling trunk, but to some officials, it is not temporary enough.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A gigantic luxury replica of a Louis Vuitton traveling trunk on Red Square in Moscow.

item.title: Latvian Premier Quits Over Deadly Building Collapse
item.description: There had been no public calls for Prime Minister Valdis Dombrovskis to resign after the collapse of a supermarket killed at least 45 people, but he said he accepted responsibility.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Amid Tensions Over Air Defense Zone, China’s Reaction Is Subdued
item.description: China said it would respond to foreign aircraft in its new air defense zone according to “how big the threat” was, after a flight by American B-52s through the airspace.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The disputed islands in the East China Sea are known as the Diaoyu by China and as the Senkaku by Japan.

item.title: Memo From South Asia: Voters in Maldives Join in Region’s Halting Steps Toward Democracy
item.description: Although elections remain far from trouble-free in countries like the Maldives, Nepal and Bhutan, that they are happening at all is encouraging.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: An election official counts votes in the Maldives on Nov. 16.

item.title: The Lede: Egypt’s Jon Stewart on Comedy and Politics
item.description: Bassem Youssef talks about the future of his show, the turbulent political situation in Egypt, and what it is like to be a comedian in a country plagued by violence, division and uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Berlusconi Expelled From Senate in Italy
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi, Italy’s once-powerful former prime minister, was stripped of his seat on Wednesday, leaving him without elective office for the first time in about two decades.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi, 77, speaking to his supporters in downtown Rome on Wednesday.

item.title: Greek Editor Acquitted Anew Over Publication of Swiss Bank Account Names
item.description: The authorities had accused Kostas Vaxevanis, who wanted to shine a light on tax evasion, of violating privacy laws.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Pakistan Names New Army Chief
item.description: The appointment of Lt. Gen. Raheel Sharif to the top military command ended months of speculation about the successor to Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Raheel Sharif served as the Pakistani Army’s inspector general of evaluation and training.

item.title: India Ink: In Raipur, Tribal Artists Finding Fewer Spaces for Self-Expression
item.description: Longtime residents of the capital of Chhattisgarh lament the loss of culture and art in the city.
item.dc:creator: By NEYAZ FAROOQUEE
item.media:credit: Namas Bhojani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Militants from the Communist Party of India (Maoist) training in a forest in Chhattisgarh in March, 2006. The constant conflicts between the Maoist rebels and the central government have made it difficult for villagers in the region to hold their traditional community gatherings.

item.title: Latvian Premier Resigns After Supermarket Disaster
item.description: Valdis Dombrovskis resigned, taking political responsibility for a supermarket collapse that killed 54 people last week and plunging the Baltic state into turmoil, just weeks before it joins the euro.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Letter From China: In China, Loss of a Child Means Orphan Parents
item.description: About 76,000 only children die annually in China, and more than a million "orphan parent" families have been created since 1980 under the one-child policy.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 27
item.description: Scientists and engineers working at the tracking center of Indian Space Research Organization in Bangalore, Karnataka.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Scientists and engineers of Indian Space Research Organization monitoring the Mars Orbiter Mission at the tracking center in Bangalore, Karnataka.

item.title: Listening Post: Airspace Claim Forces Obama to Flesh Out China Strategy
item.description: The Chinese declaration of an “air defense identification zone” led the United States to jump off the fence in a territorial dispute between China and Japan that has mushroomed into a dangerous standoff.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama and Chinese president, Xi Jinping, in Russsia in September.

item.title: Execution-Style Killings in Iraq Raise Fears of Return to Sectarian Violence
item.description: Eighteen people were killed with pinpoint deliberation, some tied up in cable, reintroducing the prospect of a return to the violence that rattled Iraq in 2006 and 2007.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Syria Will Attend Geneva Peace Talks
item.description: The Syrian government announced that a delegation will be approved by President Bashar al-Assad and that it does not intend “to hand over power to anyone.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: At War Blog: Understanding War Through Hanukkah
item.description: David Frommer, a chaplain who served in the United States Army and Israel Defense Forces, shares how his understanding of Hanukkah has evolved since his childhood.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID FROMMER
item.media:description: David Frommer leading a Jewish worship service for U.S. personnel in Kuwait, 2012.

item.title: Afghan Attacks Raise Worries on Safety of Aid Workers
item.description: Six Afghan workers employed to carry out a literacy project by a French charity were killed in an ambush on their car in Faryab Province, the second fatal attack on relief workers in two days.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: India Ink: Andhra Pradesh Set to Evacuate 250,000 people as Cyclone Lehar Nears Coast
item.description: Cylone Lehar, the second big storm in a week to threaten the state, is expected to make landfall late Thursday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: Fishermen in Puri, Odisha, on Tuesday, moving their boats away from the coast following a cyclone warning. Odisha, along with Andhra Pradesh, is expected to receive very heavy rainfall with the coming of Cyclone Lehar.

item.title: Dispute Over Immigration Widens Between Britain and E.U.
item.description: The differences surfaced weeks before limits on immigration by Bulgarian and Romanian citizens expire.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: 14 Extremists Detained in Moscow, Russian Police Say
item.description: A police statement said officers confiscated weapons, ammunition and “extremist literature” during Wednesday’s operation in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China’s Airspace Claim Inflames Ties to South Korea, Too
item.description: South Korea’s foreign minister warned that China’s attempt to police the sky over a vast area in the East China Sea was worsening tensions in a region already strained by territorial disputes.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
